description: From Middle English mad, madde, madd, medd, from Old English ƒ°em«£dd, ƒ°em«£ded (‚Äúenraged‚Äù), past participle of ƒ°em«£dan, *m«£dan (‚Äúto make insane or foolish‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *maidijanƒÖ (‚Äúto change; damage; cripple; injure; make mad‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *maidaz ("weak; crippled"; compare Old English gemƒÅd (‚Äúsilly, mad‚Äù), Old High German gimeit (‚Äúfoolish, crazy‚Äù), literary German gemeit (‚Äúmad, insane‚Äù), Gothic êå≤êå∞êåºêå∞êåπêå∏êçÉ (gamai√æs, ‚Äúcrippled‚Äù)), from Proto-Indo-European *mey- ("to change"; compare Old Irish m√°el (‚Äúbald, dull‚Äù), Old Lithuanian ap-maitinti (‚Äúto wound‚Äù), Sanskrit ‡§Æ‡•á‡§•‡§§‡§ø (m√©thati, ‚Äúhe hurts, comes to blows‚Äù)).

examples: You want to spend $1000 on a pair of shoes? Are you mad?
He's got this mad idea that he's irresistible to women.

entries.meaning: (chiefly US; informal in UK) Angry, annoyed.
(chiefly in the negative, informal) Used litotically to indicate satisfaction or approval.
examples: Wow, you really made this pie from scratch? I'm not mad at it.
It's mad that I got that job back a day after being fired.
to be mad with terror, lust, or hatred

entries.meaning: Extremely foolish or unwise; irrational; imprudent.
(colloquial, usually with for or about) Extremely enthusiastic about; crazy about; infatuated with; overcome with desire for.
examples: Aren't you just mad for that red dress?

entries.meaning: (of animals) Abnormally ferocious or furious; or, rabid, affected with rabies.
(slang, New England, New York) Intensifier, signifying abundance or high quality of a thing; very, much or many.
examples: I gotta give you mad props for scoring us those tickets. Their lead guitarist has mad skills. There are always mad girls at those parties.

entries.meaning: (of a compass needle) Having impaired polarity.
(slang, New England, New York and UK, dialect) Intensifier; to a large degree; extremely; exceedingly; very; unbelievably.
examples: He seems mad keen on her.

verbs.description: mad (third-person singular simple present mads, present participle madding, simple past and past participle madded)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To be or become mad. [14th‚Äì19th c.]
(now colloquial US, Jamaica) To madden, to anger, to frustrate. [from 15th c.]
